etymologies: early 17th century (in Scots, denoting an index or catalogue): from French répertoire, from Latin repertorium (see repertory)

definitions: a stock of plays, dances, or items that a company or a performer knows or is prepared to perform.
shortDefinitions: stock of plays, dances, or items that company or performer knows

definitions: the whole body of items that are regularly performed
shortDefinitions: whole body of items that are regularly performed

definitions: a stock of skills or types of behaviour that a person habitually uses

examples.text: his repertoire of threats, stares, and gestures

shortDefinitions: stock of skills or types of behaviour that person habitually uses
